subject: RE: [junit] ClasspathWalker (even better)
msgSnippet: ... Fine: each layer has its associated tests. I assume that the tests from a lower layer do not depend on the tests in a higher layer; otherwise you have
messageBody:
>So said Adam Jack on 2003-08-01 --------------------
>J.B wrote:
>
>> So you have one set of object-level tests and one set of API-level
>tests.
>
>Maybe, but I feel it isn't that simple. As I go up the chain, aggregate
>this/that, the dependencies build & it isn't a single layer. Maybe it is
>multiple layers.

Fine: each layer has its associated tests. I assume that the tests from a lower layer do not depend on the tests in a higher layer; otherwise you have spaghetti and not layers. Expand the idea to 'n' layers.

>> I recommend simply running them separately. If you're using
>Eclipse, place
>them in separate projects.
>> You would have three projects:
>>
>> My Production Code
>> My Object-Level Tests
>> My API-Level Tests
>
>Thanks, but...
>
>First, you stepped into my pet peeve w/ Eclipse. Run the "all tests" on one
>project and it runs all the tests on dependent projects. I believe it just
>walks the classpath not the project path. It doesn't know the difference.

Why is the Object-level Tests project in the API-level Tests project's classpath? Surely each depends on the Production Code project, but neither depends on the other!

>Second, even if I only had a few layers -- and not a complex hierarchy

You need to define "complex hierarchy" here. Is it layered or not layered? If it is layered, then the number of layers is irrelevant for the purposes of this discussion. Simply generalize to 'n'.

If it is not layered, then the design may have deeper problems that merit your immediate attention.

>I'd
>like the chance to do this within projects not at that level.

Why? What's the requirement for doing it in one project?

>Two lowest
>level tests might have what I consider a dependency.

Then they are not lowest-level tests, by definition: one is lower than the other.

>> When an API-level test fails, run the object-level tests to find
>out what
>object/method in
>> particular failed, then fix the problem.
>
>> If the API-level tests fail and the object-level tests don't fail,
>then
>you're missing an object-level
>> test, so write it.
>
>First thing I do when I see a bug is review what tests I am missing that
>should have caught it. I agree. I just do it at all levels in the stack,
>not
>at two.

As I say, generalize to 'n'.

Take care.
